flick.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to make something move away by hitting or pushing it suddenly or quickly, especially with your thumb and finger
flick.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Papa flicked the ash from his cigar.
flick.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to move with a sudden quick movement, or to make something move in this way
flick.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The cowâ€™s tail flicked from side to side.
Jackie flicked her long hair back.
flick.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to move a switch so that a machine or piece of electrical equipment starts or stops
flick.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: I felt inside the doorway and flicked the light switch.
flick.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if you flick something such as a towel or rope, you move it so that the end moves quickly away from you
flick.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The old man flicked his whip and the horses moved off.
flick.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a short quick sudden movement or hit with a part of your body, whip etc
flick.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: With a flick of the wrist, Frye sent the ball into the opposite court.
